cardData.data: The value for sales range from a minimum of 10 all the way upto a maximum of 2,754. The sum of sales amounts to 1.4 Million with the average sales per observation being 270. The dataset contains 5000 observations and there are 590 observations (outliers) that have extremely high value of sales

The histogram shows distribution of sales divided into 28 categories.

The plot indicates that the sales observations are heavily concentrated around a few categories, as more than three quarters (78.0%) of sales values are between 10 and 337. The distribution is positively skewed, which implies that there is a significant chunk of low-value sales observations.
Concentration of High & Low segments
The top 34% of the observations (High segment) account for about 67% of the total sales (1.4 Million), i.e. 909,758.

• The overall sales from the bottom quartile (28% of observations low sales) amounts to 91,734, which is just 6% of the total.
  • The average sales per observations for the top performing segment is 522, which is 1.93 times that of the overall average sales per observation (270) and 7.0 times that of the mean value from Low segment.
Sales: Impact of Discount_Range on Sales

chartInfo: Inference   : There is a significant effect of Discount_Range on Sales (target).

cardData.data: The top two Discount_Ranges(21 to 30 percent and 31 to 40 percent) account for about 61% of the total Sales. Being the largest contributor, 21 to 30 percent amounts to 507,507 that accounts for about 37.57% of the total Sales. However, 0 to 10 percent has the highest average Sales of 399, whereas the average for 21 to 30 percent is 293. On the other hand, 0 to 10 percent contributes to just 9% of the total Sales.
Key Factors influencing Sales from 21 to 30 percent

High contribution of Sales from 21 to 30 percent is characterized by the influence of key dimensions, such as Deal_Type, Source, and Buyer_Age. Certain specific segment from those dimensions are more likely to explain 21 to 30 percent's significant Sales turnover.

• Buyer_Age - The top 6 Buyer_Age account for 56.0% of the Sales from 21 to 30 percent.
  • Source - Among the Source, top 4 Source account for 58.0% of the total Sales.
  • Deal_Type - Among the Deal_Type, Gourmet has got the major chunk of Sales from 21 to 30 percent, accounting for 16.0%.
Sales: Impact of Source on Sales

chartInfo: Inference   : There is a significant effect of Source on Sales (target).

cardData.data: The top two Sources(Google Ads and Facebook Page) account for about 45% of the total Sales. Being the largest contributor, Google Ads amounts to 434,749 that accounts for about 32.18% of the total Sales. However, Facebook Page has the highest average Sales of 288, whereas the average for Google Ads is 263. On the other hand, Facebook Ads contributes to just 6% of the total Sales.
Key Factors influencing Sales from Google Ads

High contribution of Sales from Google Ads is characterized by the influence of key dimensions, such as Discount_Range, Deal_Type, and Buyer_Age. Certain specific segment from those dimensions are more likely to explain Google Ads's significant Sales turnover.

• Buyer_Age - The top 3 Buyer_Age account for 55.0% of the Sales from Google Ads.
  • Deal_Type - Among the Deal_Type, top 5 Deal_Type account for 48.0% of the total Sales.
  • Discount_Range - Among the Discount_Range, 21 to 30 percent has got the major chunk of Sales from Google Ads, accounting for 35.0%.

chartInfo: Inference   : There is a significant effect of Deal_Type on Sales (target).

cardData.data: Sales contribution from each of the Deal_Types seems to be similar. Being the largest contributor, Gourmet amounts to 219,807 that accounts for about 16.27% of the total Sales. However, National has the highest average Sales of 288, whereas the average for Gourmet is 270.
Key Factors influencing Sales from Gourmet

High contribution of Sales from Gourmet is characterized by the influence of key dimensions, such as Discount_Range, Buyer_Age, and Source. Certain specific segment from those dimensions are more likely to explain Gourmet's significant Sales turnover.

• Source - The top 5 Source account for 60.0% of the Sales from Gourmet.

  • Discount_Range - Among the Discount_Range, 21 to 30 percent has got the major chunk of Sales from Gourmet, accounting for 37.0%.

chartInfo: Inference   : There is a significant effect of Buyer_Age on Sales (target).

High contribution of Sales from 25 to 34 is characterized by the influence of key dimensions, such as Discount_Range, Source, and Deal_Type. Certain specific segment from those dimensions are more likely to explain 25 to 34's significant Sales turnover.

chartInfo: Inference   : There is a significant effect of Platform on Sales (target).

cardData.data: The top Platforms(Desktop) account for about 74% of the total Sales. Being the largest contributor, Desktop amounts to 1.0 Million that accounts for about 74.76% of the total Sales. However, Mobile has the highest average Sales of 273, whereas the average for Desktop is 269.

High contribution of Sales from Desktop is characterized by the influence of key dimensions, such as Discount_Range, Source, and Deal_Type. Certain specific segment from those dimensions are more likely to explain Desktop's significant Sales turnover.

• Deal_Type - The top 5 Deal_Type account for 46.0% of the Sales from Desktop.
  • Source - Among the Source, top 5 Source account for 58.0% of the total Sales.
  • Discount_Range - Among the Discount_Range, 21 to 30 percent has got the major chunk of Sales from Desktop, accounting for 38.0%.

There are 7 dimensions in the dataset and 6 of them(including Discount_Range, Source, Deal_Type, etc.) have significant influence on Sales. It implies that specific categories within each of the dimensions show considerable amount of variation in Sales. However Price_Range donâ€™t show significant difference in Sales values across categories.

chartInfo: Inference         : There are 6 variables that have significant association with the Sales (Target) and the                      Effect size ranges from 0.0001 to 0.0

cardData.data: The chart above displays the impact of key dimensions on Sales, as measured by effect size. Let us take a deeper look at some of the most important dimensions that show significant amount of difference in average Sales.
Impact of Marketing_Cost on Sales
Overview

Marketing_Cost is one of the significant influencer of Sales and it explains a great magnitude of change in Sales. It is positively & strongly correlated with the Sales figures. As Marketing_Cost changes, Sales also tend to move in the same direction. An incremental unit change in Marketing_Cost corresponds to an average decrease in Sales by -28.18 units.
Sensitivity Analysis

Marketing_Cost seems to have a remarkable impact on various segments of Sales observations. The chart above shows four quadrants based on the distribution of Sales (high vs. low) and Marketing_Cost (high vs. low).

chartInfo: Inference     : For every additional unit of decrease in Marketing_Cost there will be an decrease of -28.18 units in Sales (target).

cardData.data: High Sales with High Marketing_Cost: The Sales observations from this quadrant are typically from Desktop (Platform),Male (Buyer_Gender) and 21 to 30 percent (Discount_Range). It accounts for about 21.0% of the total population.
Low Sales with Low Marketing_Cost: Mostly Sales from Desktop (Platform), Male (Buyer_Gender) and Google Ads (Source) belong to this segment. They cover nearly 57.0% of the total population.

High Sales with Low Marketing_Cost: Nearly 10.0% of the total observations are from this group and they are generally coming from Desktop (Platform),Female (Buyer_Gender) and 21 to 30 percent (Discount_Range).
Low Sales with High Marketing_Cost: Nearly 9.0% of the total observations are from this group and they are generally coming from Desktop (Platform), Female (Buyer_Gender) and Google Ads (Source).
Impact of Tenure_in_Days on Sales
Overview

Tenure_in_Days is one of the significant influencer of Sales and it explains a great magnitude of change in Sales. It is positively correlated with the Sales figures. An incremental unit change in Tenure_in_Days corresponds to an average increase in Sales by 12.94 units.
Sensitivity Analysis

Tenure_in_Days seems to have a remarkable impact on various segments of Sales observations. The chart above shows four quadrants based on the distribution of Sales (high vs. low) and Tenure_in_Days (high vs. low).

chartInfo: Inference     : For every additional unit of increase in Tenure_in_Days there will be an increase of 12.94 units in Sales (target).

Low Sales with Low Tenure_in_Days: Mostly Sales from Desktop (Platform), Female (Buyer_Gender) and Google Ads (Source) belong to this segment. They cover nearly 34.0% of the total population.

High Sales with Low Tenure_in_Days: Nearly 16.0% of the total observations are from this group and they are generally coming from Desktop (Platform),Male (Buyer_Gender) and 21 to 30 percent (Discount_Range).
Low Sales with High Tenure_in_Days: Nearly 32.0% of the total observations are from this group and they are generally coming from Desktop (Platform), Male (Buyer_Gender) and Google Ads (Source).
Impact of Last_Transaction on Sales
Overview

Last_Transaction is one of the significant influencer of Sales and it explains a great magnitude of change in Sales. It is positively & strongly correlated with the Sales figures. As Last_Transaction changes, Sales also tend to move in the same direction. An incremental unit change in Last_Transaction corresponds to an average increase in Sales by 0.71 units.
Sensitivity Analysis

Last_Transaction seems to have a remarkable impact on various segments of Sales observations. The chart above shows four quadrants based on the distribution of Sales (high vs. low) and Last_Transaction (high vs. low).

chartInfo: Inference     : For every additional unit of increase in Last_Transaction there will be an increase of 0.71 units in Sales (target).

cardData.data: High Sales with High Last_Transaction: The Sales observations from this quadrant are typically from Desktop (Platform),Male (Buyer_Gender) and 21 to 30 percent (Discount_Range). It accounts for about 26.0% of the total population.
Low Sales with Low Last_Transaction: Mostly Sales from Desktop (Platform), Male (Buyer_Gender) and Google Ads (Source) belong to this segment. They cover nearly 60.0% of the total population.

High Sales with Low Last_Transaction: Nearly 6.0% of the total observations are from this group and they are generally coming from Desktop (Platform),Female (Buyer_Gender) and 21 to 30 percent (Discount_Range).

Low Sales with High Last_Transaction: Nearly 6.0% of the total observations are from this group and they are generally coming from Desktop (Platform), Female (Buyer_Gender) and 21 to 30 percent (Discount_Range).
Key Measures that affect Sales

There are 5 measures in the dataset and three of them (Marketing_Cost, Tenure_in_Days and Last_Transaction) have significant influence on Sales. It implies that these measures explain considerable amount of variation in Sales figures. However Shipping_Cost donâ€™t show significant difference in Sales values across categories. The chart below displays the impact of key Measures on Sales, as measured by effect size.
